definition: Necrotizing small-vessel vasculitis (pauci-immune) affecting capillaries (esp. in kidneys & lungs); an **ANCA**-associated disease with no granulomas.
why_it_matters: Life-threatening cause of alveolar hemorrhage & rapidly progressive GN that is fatal if untreated; early immunosuppression can save organs and lives.
how_youll_see_it: Systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, arthralgias) followed by **RPGN** (hematuria, RBC casts, ↑creatinine) ± **pulmonary capillaritis** (hemoptysis, cough, dyspnea) – classic pulmonary–renal syndrome.
Renal-limited variant: isolated **pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis** without lung involvement (ANCA-positive rapidly progressive GN).

Other features: **palpable purpura** (skin), mononeuritis multiplex (peripheral nerves), and sometimes GI vasculitis (abdominal pain). **Upper respiratory** tract involvement is notably absent (unlike GPA).
problem_solving: Order **ANCA** serologies: MPA is usually **MPO-ANCA** (p-ANCA) positive; also check **anti-GBM** to exclude Goodpasture's in pulmonary–renal cases.
Confirm with tissue **biopsy** (often kidney): shows pauci-immune necrotizing vasculitis (crescentic GN) without granulomas.
Determine disease severity (organ-threatening vs limited) – e.g., glomerulonephritis or alveolar hemorrhage necessitate aggressive therapy.
Do not delay treatment in severe disease: start high-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide/rituximab promptly to prevent irreversible damage.

differentials.hint: nasal + sinus inflammation, nodules/cavities; **c-ANCA** (PR3); granulomas present
asthma, eosinophilia; p-ANCA (~50%); granulomas with eosinophils
medium vessels; spares lungs/glomeruli; often linked to Hep B; typically ANCA-negative

differentials.name: Goodpasture (anti-GBM) disease
differentials.hint: alveolar hemorrhage + GN but linear IgG deposits (anti-GBM+); not ANCA-associated

tricks: No **ENT** involvement or granulomas in MPA (distinguishes it from GPA).
exam_appearance: Middle-aged adult with hemoptysis, dyspnea, rapidly rising creatinine, and p-ANCA positivity → microscopic polyangiitis (pulmonary–renal syndrome).
Patient with subacute hematuria, proteinuria, and anemia; kidney biopsy shows crescentic pauci-immune GN (ANCA-positive) → renal-limited microscopic polyangiitis.
treatment: Remission induction: high-dose **corticosteroids** + either **cyclophosphamide** or **rituximab** (for severe organ-threatening disease). Use **methotrexate** or **MMF** only in mild cases (no critical organ involvement).
Maintenance: after remission, switch to a less toxic agent for 1–2+ years (e.g., **azathioprine** or periodic rituximab) to prevent relapse.
Adjuncts: consider **plasmapheresis** if life-threatening renal or pulmonary failure (controversial); give **PJP prophylaxis** (TMP-SMX) during intensive immunosuppression.
red_flags: Diffuse **alveolar hemorrhage** (hemoptysis, hypoxia, new infiltrates) → ICU-level emergency; requires immediate high-dose immunosuppression (risk of respiratory failure).
**Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis** (quick rise in creatinine with RBC casts) → start aggressive therapy without delay to prevent irreversible renal failure.
algorithm: Suspicion: patient with hematuria (± hemoptysis) and systemic inflammation → evaluate for ANCA-associated vasculitis.
Initial workup: send **ANCA panel** (MPO & PR3); check anti-GBM; get chest imaging if respiratory symptoms; basic labs (creatinine, UA).
Confirm diagnosis with **biopsy** of affected organ (often kidney) showing pauci-immune vasculitis (necrotizing GN).

If organ-threatening disease, begin induction therapy immediately (do not wait for biopsy) – high-dose steroids + cyclophosphamide or rituximab (consider plasma exchange for very severe renal failure).
After remission, continue **maintenance immunosuppression** (e.g., azathioprine or periodic rituximab) for 24–48 months; monitor for relapse.

cases.stem: A 55‑year‑old man develops acute-onset hemoptysis and dark urine.
clues: Cough with blood-tinged sputum and diffuse lung infiltrates
Hematuria with red cell casts; rapidly rising creatinine
cases.teaching: This is a classic presentation of MPA causing diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and RPGN. MPO-ANCA positivity and a pauci-immune crescentic GN confirm an ANCA-associated vasculitis (distinguishing it from Goodpasture's, which is anti-GBM positive). Prompt treatment with steroids and cyclophosphamide or rituximab is critical.

cases.stem: A 63‑year‑old woman is evaluated for progressive fatigue and new-onset edema.
clues: No pulmonary symptoms; focus is on renal issues
cases.teaching: MPA can present as isolated pauci-immune glomerulonephritis without lung involvement. The positive p-ANCA and kidney biopsy confirm an ANCA-associated vasculitis limited to the kidneys. Treatment is similar (immunosuppression) to prevent progression to end-stage renal disease.
